awd_titl_txt: The Central Protuberance Region of the Yeast Mitoribosome and its Role in Regulating OXPHOS Complex Biogenesis
awd_abstract_narration:
Mitochondria are commonly referred to as the 'powerhouse' of the cell because they produce the vital energy currency of the cell, ATP. The synthesis of ATP occurs through a process termed oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS), catalyzed by multisubunit enzymes composed mainly of proteins encoded by the nuclear genome. A small, but enzymatically important, subset of OXPHOS proteins are encoded on the mitochondrial genome and synthesized by mitochondrial ribosomes (mitoribosomes). This project seeks to understand the molecular mechanisms that regulate mitoribosome activity, and thus has important implications for the OXPHOS complex assembly and the bioenergetic capacity of the cell. Providing opportunities for both undergraduate and graduate students, this project seeks to advance STEM discovery while promoting hands-on learning and training.  Professional development opportunities to aid students with career and/or graduate school preparedness, with a focus on women, underrepresented minorities and first-generation students, will also be promoted.

Evolutionarily related to prokaryotic ribosomes, mitoribosomes have evolved to contain novel mitospecific features, the functions of which are largely unexplored. This project is focused on the molecular dissection of the mitospecific protein MrpL35/mL38, and its partner Mrp7/bL27, located in the central protuberance (CP) region of the yeast mitoribosome. The PI's recent findings have highlighted the CP as a key regulatory region of the mitoribosome, serving to ensure coordination of the translational process with the downstream, chaperoned events of OXPHOS complex assembly. The outcomes of this project will be directly applicable to those working on mitochondrial biogenesis, OXPHOS, and the function and evolution of ribosomal systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation (OXPHOS) is the biochemical process that cells use to produce ATP, the vital energy source for a cell's diverse metabolic needs. The enzymes involved in the OXPHOS pathway are composed many different protein subunits, the majority of which are encoded by the nuclear genome. A small, but enzymatically critical, number of OXPHOS subunits are encoded on the mitochondrial genome and are synthesized by mitochondrial ribosomes (mitoribosomes) within the mitochondrial matrix. The biogenesis of the OXPHOS enzymes relies on the ability of the mitochondrially synthesized proteins to effectively co-assemble with their nuclear encoded partners imported into the organelle following their synthesis in the cytosol. The process of protein synthesis performed by the mitoribosome and its regulation, is thus key to understanding the biogenesis of mitochondrial OXPHOS system and the respiratory capacity of the cell. 

Evolutionarily related to bacterial ribosomes, the mitoribosome has evolved to contain a number of protein features unique to the mitochondria, so-called “mitospecific” mitoribosomal features. At the outset of this award, it had been suggested in the field that the mitoribosome operates in a coupled and coordinated fashion with the import and assembly of nuclear encoded OXPHOS subunits, and that the coordination and regulation of the mitoribosome specifically involves mitospecific protein aspects of the mitoribosome. The goal of this current award was to use the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae (S. cerevisiae) to explore the functional significance of two mitoribosomal proteins - MrpL35/mL38, a mitospecific protein, and Mrp7/bL27m, a mitoribosomal protein with a bacterial ancestor (bL27) but evolved to contain a large C-terminal mitospecific extension sequence of unknown relevance. CryoEM analysis of mitoribosomes from across different species have indicated that MrpL35/mL38 and Mrp7/bL27m are physically associated with each other and are located in the central protuberance (CP) region of the mitoribosome.

Through a series of site-directed mutagenesis, domain deletion studies, and combined yeast genetic and biochemical approaches, we functionally characterized the yeast MrpL35/mL38 and Mrp7/bL27m proteins. Collectively, our analysis of MrpL35/mL38 and Mrp7/bL27 proteins has indicated that both proteins are required for OXPHOS biogenesis, but the primary impact of their mutation was not an inhibition of the mitochondrial translational process per se, but rather on events that affected the post-translational fate of newly synthesized proteins. Our findings with the generated mrpL35 and mrp7 mutants indicated the processes of mitochondrial translation and the downstream events of assembling newly synthesized mtDNA encoded proteins into OXPHOS complexes are not always tightly coupled, contrary to current dogma in the field. Rather, our data supported that the CP region of the mitoribosome plays an important regulatory role in coordinating the fate of the newly synthesized proteins by influencing the partitioning of nascent chains between the steps that can either lead to their stable assembly in OXPHOS complexes or to those that promote their proteolytic turnover. Furthermore, based on our findings, we postulate that elements of MrpL35/mL38 and Mrp7/bL27 exposed to the external face of the mitoribosome may serve to bind external regulatory factors, possibly through the ligand-binding “phosphatidyl ethanolamine-like” (PEBP-like) domain of MrpL35/mL38. This in turn may influence the behavior and translational integrity of the ribosome at the peptidyl transferase center, the active site of the ribosome and thus the competency of resulting nascent chains to effectively assemble into OXPHOS enzymes. 

In addition to discovering the processes of mitotranslation and OXPHOS complex assembly can be uncoupled in mrpL35 and mrp7 mutants, we also demonstrated that in wild type yeast cells the mitoribosome continues to synthesize proteins irrespective of the cellular demand for OXPHOS assembly, i.e. contrary to expectations, the cellular level of mitochondrial translation is not suppressed when OXPHOS assembly is suppressed. Moreover, our findings indicated that maintaining a high level of mitochondrial translation during glycolysis-based metabolism strongly influenced the cell’s ability to adapt and effectively switch its metabolism from a glycolysis- to a respiratory-based metabolism, when required. Collectively, our findings suggest that the process of mitoribosomal protein translation may not exist for the sole purpose of synthesizing mtDNA encoded components for OXPHOS complex biogenesis, but it also may serve as a synthesis source of signaling molecules, required to signal integrity of the mitochondrial genome and ensuring the cell’s capacity for metabolic flexibility.  

Broader Impacts – a central aspect of the funded work focused on the training and mentoring of younger scientists. Undergraduate students were involved in the described research activities through creation of course-based undergraduate research experiences (CURE) taught by the PI. In addition, research activities provided training opportunities for a graduate student and undergraduate students in the PI lab. Combined with several course-based career discernment and preparedness initiatives, the PI placed a continued emphasis on the training and career development of students.
